turns.speaker: YUNG
turns.text: The drill is in the water; approaching the intake tunnel.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Excellent.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Please, Sidney. I'd like to remember you fondly.

turns.speaker: YUNG
turns.text: Approaching the first gate.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Start the grinders.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Bore through.  ...They used to say living well was the best revenge, Mr. Bond.  They're wrong.  Revenge is the best revenge.

turns.speaker: YUNG
turns.text: Entering the main tunnel - ten minutes to target -

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Hong Kong, Mr. Bond!

turns.speaker: YUNG
turns.text: You have to leave -

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: A hundred and fifty years ago, my ancestors took this island - a barren, lifeless rock - and turned it into the greatest city known to modern civilization.  And now that I'm being forced to give it back, I intend to return it in exactly the same condition: A barren, lifeless rock.  The gold is merely reparations - payment from the spineless British government who wouldn't listen.

turns.speaker: YUNG
turns.text: Take the men. I can finish alone.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: You come with me -  You stay here.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Is the helicopter ready?

turns.speaker: STAMPER
turns.text: Fueled and waiting.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Good. We have an appointment in Hong Kong.

turns.speaker: STAMPER
turns.text: It's a trick! After him.  They're in the south stairwell!

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Get more men up there!

turns.speaker: STAMPER
turns.text: They're on the bridge. Seal off the 50th floor!

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: I should have hired this man.  Get somebody up there!

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: - Built to withstand a nuclear blast.  Are they alive?

turns.speaker: STAMPER
turns.text: Yes. Shall we kill them?

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: No. I have a better idea. In fact, Mr. Bond may have actually improved my original plan.  Bring them both to Hong Kong. And Make sure he has nothing else up his sleeve.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: What the hell is going on?

turns.speaker: STAMPER
turns.text: It's Bond!

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Kill him! Finish it!

turns.speaker: NUMBER THREE
turns.text: I regret to inform you, sir, that Saddam Hussein is still demanding a bonus for his role in the Gulf War.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: ...Haven't we already paid him for his services?

turns.speaker: NUMBER THREE
turns.text: Yes, sir. But he still feels his people should share in the increased profits of our news division. He has proposed an additional 500 million dollar payment.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: ... And there's no truth that 10% of that money will go into your Swiss bank account?

turns.speaker: NUMBER THREE
turns.text: No sir! I swear! This is not true!!

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: You disappoint me, Number Three.

turns.speaker: NUMBER THREE
turns.text: Please sir. Please -

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: ...But because I am a just man, I've decided to give Mr. Hussein what he deserves.

turns.speaker: HARMSWAY
turns.text: Mr. Stamper will escort you to the plane.

turns.speaker: NUMBER THREE
turns.text: Thank you sir! Thank you!

turns.speaker: M
turns.text: What about ID's?

turns.speaker: TANNER
turns.text: One to seven: Deal the face cards.

turns.speaker: TANNER
turns.text: Oh, no.

turns.speaker: M
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: TANNER
turns.text: Kim Dae Yung. North Korean Nuclear specialist.

turns.speaker: M
turns.text: Meaning there may be nuclear material down there?

turns.speaker: M
turns.text: Who is that?!? What's in the box??

turns.speaker: TANNER
turns.text: I don't know. He's not in the database -

turns.speaker: M
turns.text: What's in the box, General?  What's in the box???

turns.speaker: M
turns.text: Will it go off?

turns.speaker: TANNER
turns.text: Maybe. Maybe not.

turns.speaker: M
turns.text: Abort the cruise.

turns.speaker: TANNER
turns.text: Soviet SB-9 nuclear torpedo. Yield, one kiloton.

turns.speaker: M
turns.text: Will the cruise set it off?

turns.speaker: TANNER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: What time is it? Do you think you can just treat us like your slave? It's after one.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I tried to call to let you know I was going to be late.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: That's a lie.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I pay my own way.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Since when?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Your mother asked me not to mention it but your mother's birthday was last week.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I hadn't forgotten. I ordered some cloth but it didn't come in and I felt so bad if I would have come to her birthday without that, I just stayed at home.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: What did your wife get her?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: We got the same thing.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Why, you don't want us to bring him over?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: No, it's that when do you have time to be parents to him? You guys don't pick him up until nine, ten at night. You are into yourselves, as the saying goes. Spend some time trying to be parents. Take him to the mountains, fishing. You ought to let him get to know nature.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Well, you are his grandfather. He is supposed to spend some time with you. You're supposed to show him those woodsy things and this and that.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Junior spends time with his child.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Oh here we go with that.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Babe Brother, is that my shirt that you're wearing?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: How come you're not wearing my shoes?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: They're too big.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: When are you boys going to fix that roof?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Soon as I rest a bit.  I meant as soon as we are back to normal again, anytime.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Here I am thinking about myself when poor Harry is resting on the floor of the kitchen.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: When are you going to find time to help me fix the roof?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: You all don't believe me when I tell you I'm afraid of heights.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: You used that excuse to get out of the army.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: You always got something to say.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: You want me to mortgage my house to invest in a scheme of yours? You know the last time we went into something together Daddy had to go in his savings to keep us from ending on the street.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Why are you always afraid to get somewhere?

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: This is not a good time to take chances. Your best friend, Robert, an accountant, lost his home and is out on the street. We see him from time to time. He comes down to church for a free meal.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: This is what it is all about, trying to keep from being out on the street.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: Robert asks about you. When are you going to do something to help him?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Maybe I can get down there next week.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: Why in the hell didn't you help mama?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I told her I would if she would give me time.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: I bet you if your master would have told you to fix the hole in the roof, you would have rebuilt the whole damn house.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: You always got the best of it around here and when Dad always talks about my son, it is always you, so you fix the roof.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: That is a damn lie and you know it. Every time father asks you to do something, you either half-ass do it or run off and hide. Mama asked you to turn the dirt in her garden and you told her, with your smart ass self, that you weren't a farmer; get Junior to do it. Every time someone asks you to do something, you always say, tell Junior to do it. Boy, you ought to grow up.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I told you about calling me boy. I ain't no boy. See, you and Dad got a bad habit of calling me boy. You call me boy in front of my wife. You think I'm going to fix the roof? I hope the wind blows the whole damn thing off and it pours down rain.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: I ought to break your damn neck.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I'm leaving and don't even call me when the shoe falls 'cause all he did for me was to try and run my life. I'm tired of people saying Babe Brother this, Babe Brother that. What's my name?

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: You dumb ass, it's Babe Brother.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: My name is Sam. Samuel.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I'll drive her to the hospital.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: We will take her. You all stay here and watch Dad.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I'm cold. I need to get out into the sunlight.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: What is it, noontime?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Because you were spoiled, don't try to spoil Sunny.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: My daddy never gave me anything without my having to sweat for it. Every summer, the way they kept me and Junior out of trouble was to send us to Big Daddy's farm. We would get up with the chickens. Every summer the fence had to be repaired. The barn needed a coat of paint. We had to pip all of Big Mama's hundred laying hens and go to church all day on Sunday. For Big Daddy, calluses and sweat were the mark of a man. Sunny will never have to bust his knuckles like we did.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I want Sunny to have an advantage that you and I never had, but he needs discipline, and you are not helping when I tell him to do something and you allow him to get out of it.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: What is a sip of coffee going to do?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Coffee is bad for anybody, especially for a child.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I don't see you crying about my drinking it.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: How old are you?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Why don't you come in for a while?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I would like to finish reading this. What would I talk about? I haven't read this month's almanac. I don't care to hear about how the corn was this fall or how to get rid of gophers by putting garlic in their holes. They pride themselves in making life hard and that's not my cup of tea.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You would think people never lived in a house if they have to ask what does 1 1/2 baths mean.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Will you still get the money from your father?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I told him we might not need it, if you can talk your parents into giving you your share of the property.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Pops put Big Daddy's farm in Rhonda's and Sunny's name and fixed it so no one can borrow on it.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: We could borrow on that land and put the money to work.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I preached to Mom and Dad about it but they are stuck in their ways, it's like talking to a brick. But if there is a way...

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Why does he always pick on me?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He is just being like all parents, concerned about the ones they love.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I don't need that kind of love. And I don't want to be reminded all the time that Big Mama's grandmother was born in slavery. If you really care about me, just tell me how I can make money.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Linda, how come you don't see that Sunny puts his shoes on right?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Why in the h...

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I'm okay. Go back to your friends.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I have more sense than to give up everything, my family, you and Sunny. It wasn't me, I mean the real me inside my body. I'm glad it's over. It's like a veil has been lifted.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Like a veil has been lifted?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: It's like I've been swimming in muddy waters.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Like muddy waters?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: It was like all those things old country people try to tell you what hell is like.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You were in hell?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I couldn't believe the things I was doing. It was like an internal struggle going on inside my body.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Do you think you won?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: It was nip and tuck.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: And what lesson have we learned from all of this, Babe Br... Sam... I mean Samuel?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I guess it proves you really care about me. You hung in there.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Babe Brother.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I was hoping you came to the door instead of him. It gets cold at night.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: This doesn't make any sense; you are going to drag that poor boy out in the cold air.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: He will be alright.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Doesn't he look a whole of lot better?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Well, you look better than you did yesterday.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I need to get my suitcase out of the garage.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I'm going back home with Harry.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I've heard some foolish things in my life.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Harry is coming to pick me up.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Have you lost your mind? Have you thought about your wife and child, not to mention your sick father? And I need your help to move his bed from under the leak in the ceiling.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I'm busy.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Don't make me raise my hand to you. You have to see for yourself that you are going in the wrong direction.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Can't I be myself without you jumping in with your right and wrong? The world is not black and white. Show me one perfect person. If you can't, don't ask me to be.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I do have a right to ask you to be a little bit better than me and your father because we gave you a better head start. You have no right to complain to us about your not having enough.  You sit right there with your no manners self.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Did you ever have to use this thing?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That is called a crab apple switch. It's for those bad acting monkeys and just the thing for a mean dog. Now I don't know if I actually did what I did or got my life and story mixed in with other folk's stories but I seem to recall that I had to use my crab apple on a boy from back home. I was up in Memphis working on the railroad, like your daddy who had an easy job. He would sing a song that had a cadence and we would lay track. Anyway I was coming down Beale Street and I heard this music coming from a saloon. Sure enough it was Emory. My daddy taught both of us to play but Emory was natural at it. Got in a blues band and what not. He and another boy had killed a boy named Hocker sometime back and they balled the Jack leaving town. Emory had lost one eye and had a scar running down his face. Bad luck I would say. He got to drinking that corn liquor. We went to his girl's room and he wouldn't stop drinking. He started talking about the old days and he went mad. He pulled his knife and I got to mine first. The lights went out.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Don't pick up the cards if you are not in the game. Did he die?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I don't know what happened to him. He just ran out into the streets.  I got some old records I want you to hear. I like the blues sung simply, man and a guitar. Or sung by a woman who had bad luck all her life. Don't ever let anyone tell you his life's story if it is of a weary life full of sadness. When I was a boy, a man told me a story of how he lost all of his sons and I'll be damned if the same thing didn't happen to me.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Boy, that is the real South. That is real corn liquor.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Never play with someone's else's cards. You always get a new deck. Look at this card. See anything?

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: It is just a regular card.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Son, I can take everything you got with that deck. It is marked. Now I'm going to show you how to make some money in case you get stuck somewhere.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Son, would you do me a favor and see if you could turn off that tap in the bathroom. My hand is too weak. And would you do me another favor? I don't like asking this but would you clean the tub for me? I have trouble bending over.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: Anytime you need someone to do something for you, just let me know.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I could swear I heard my son call me.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You probably heard the wind stirring up those dead leaves over there.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: I heard his voice as clear as day. I better get back. Maybe something is wrong.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I don't want to wear out welcome, but you can stay in someone's heart longer than you can stay in their house. Come with us, boy. We are going to have a good time.

turns.speaker: BABE BROTHER
turns.text: This would be a bad time for me to leave.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: We are going where the action is. Ain't that right, Okra?  Let's play for a couple of bucks unless you want to start off with two bits and work our way up.  What would you give to be rich?

turns.speaker: DAVIS
turns.text: You know it is against the city ordinance to keep chickens or live stock.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I always had chickens, ducks and whatnots.

turns.speaker: DAVIS
turns.text: Not anymore, not in the city.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: We grow most of our own food. The money I get from social security, my pension and my wife's work, keeps us living on the edge. What choice do people like us have.

turns.speaker: DAVIS
turns.text: Well, you just have to move further out.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Now how far would further out be?

turns.speaker: DAVIS
turns.text: I'm not here to argue, sir.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: My mind plays tricks on me. Is it okay if I take a bath now?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Everyone is gone. Rhonda is in the bathroom.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Babe Brother and his wife are taking advantage of a situation. I hate to be mean to people but picking Sunny up when they feel like it has to come to an end. Now I'm going to ask him how come he couldn't be at your birthday.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Don't bother the poor boy. It just takes some people a little longer to figure out who they are.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I don't know how two brothers can be so different.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Let us settle this tomorrow.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Look! Don't try to get ahead by riding our backs.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Your feet are cold.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Go back to sleep.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I asked you to wake me when Babe Brother comes.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You all act like two roosters.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I'm not going to let him get away with murder.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You and Babe Brother are so much alike...

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: He ain't nothing like me. How come a man has to have sons that are day and night apart? You ought to stop protecting him.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Hush.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: You're always taking his side.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Hush.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I'm trying to make him a man but you keep babying him.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You're going to find yourself on the floor.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You know, Babe Brother's wife just dumps greens in the pot without washing them.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Babe Brother is a poor boy.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Well, it's up to Suzie.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: It would be nice.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Do you want your coat? It's cold out here.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: No, I'm too hot now.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You better be careful. You'll get a stroke arguing.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I wouldn't care if I drop dead if he learn something from it.  Son, you make me wish I was dead.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Gideon, don't say things like that.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Let us go back in before the night of celebration becomes a night of me killing my son.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: No. Before anyone moves, you two shake hands and don't carry it any further.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I'm worn out.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Just stay in bed and rest.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I have to feed the chickens before they wake everybody up.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You stay inside. I will see to them.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I will appreciate that.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: It's good to be able to hear that.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You must have been really sick.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: How is the garden doing?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I need to get out there and get those weeds out.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: How is that hen doing? I was meaning to pip her before I fell sick.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: What, are you having another party?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You better come sit down. You are still sick.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Gal, you're talking to John Henry. When was I sick?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Since this morning.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: What happened to your hand?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I cut it on an old rusty knife.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: What did you put on it?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: It's healing now.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: He's going to check out heaven first. He gets a round trip ticket to heaven. He gets in heaven and finds it just like back home. People dripping with sweat, working in the fields, hardly surviving. He asked a man who was getting a drink of water, "I thought the streets were paved with gold." "They are but you won't see them," he said. "Boy, you got to work day and night cause idleness is sinfulness." So he takes the other half of his ticket and takes the express to hell. He sees people stretched out on their backs kicking back, picking their teeth. "Man, this is a dream." He asked, "What's you'll doing?" They all hollered back, "Sinning." The devil was shaking hands with everyone and came up to him and said, "Please to meet you." He asked, "I thought you'll was supposed to be burning in fire." Someone said, "Man, ain't no fire down here except under that pot of chitlins." The man was going go ask the preacher back on earth...

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I don't want to hear any joke about colored people being in hell. You're being irreverent.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I'm almost finished. I'm about to come to the punch line.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I don't want to hear any tales about colored people...

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: But these are white people, anybody. The punch...

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I don't care to hear any jokes about people being in hell. This cut on my hand reminds me that it is nothing to laugh at.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: It's only a tale.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: This is my grandson, Sunny. He is my youngest son's child.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: He kind of favors one of my boys when he was about his age.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Boy, that is bad luck to touch a fellow with a broom.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: He knows better. Sunny, apologize to Harry.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I came all the way from Detroit by bus going to Oakland. The bus stopped in Los Angeles. I had to get off and take a rest. I'll catch the last bus leaving at midnight. I'm just too tired to go on.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Why didn't you catch a plane?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: My feet have never been on anything that wasn't directly attached to the ground.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Stay until you feel better? I would like to hear all the news.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm worn out but won't you feel like you are taking in a stranger?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Man, put your boxes down and stay as long as you like. We have empty rooms since the boys got their own families and moved out.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well if you're sure, I won't be a bother. Oh, I don't sleep on no spring mattress. I always make myself a pallet on the floor.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Man, act like this is your home.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That's awful generous of you. I always ask to keep from wearing out welcome.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: It's the boy next door throwing at his birds. I'm just waiting on him to hit a pane in the window

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm going to wash up now. You all please excuse me.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: You ought to come hear our preacher. Remember old Cat Iron? Well, our preacher is just as strong.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Next time when I feel a little better perhaps.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I was going to get up and get a hen out there for dinner, but time got away.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, I would feel much at home if you let me get one for you. I haven't wrung a chicken's neck in a month of Sundays. You know, folks would call my daddy to kill their hogs. That used to be my trade from time to time.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Well, I would appreciate that.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: How often is your wife called to help delivery?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: It was slow. Now it seems like everyone is having births at home.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: What could have caused this? I just changed this damn thing.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Everything these days is made overseas.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: You and Babe Brother hit it off so well.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Course, it is your business, but I feel obliged to tell you that maybe you have not been fair with the boy.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I tried to teach him right from wrong just like I did his Junior.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Everyone has to follow his own plough. A man doesn't have to know how to cut a wick and clean a chimney nowadays. City people don't give a hoot and a holler about the shape of the moon nowadays. You don't plant old ways...  ... but, at the end, you find yourself doing what your father did but you have to have the land in you.  It's when you want to give the house or farm to the kids and they don't want it. You sell it to a stranger. You worked your whole life, for what?  I doubt if people nowadays have knowledge of a victory garden or seen an inch worm. All what we've experienced has no meaning.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: You're suppose to teach your children what you know. Junior, I don't have to worry about. Babe Brother is a different story.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You still call him boy. You call Babe Brother boy in front of his wife and son.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: My daddy called me boy up to the time he died. I was always boy to him.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: 'Course, you could be right. Your sons are alive. All my sons are dead.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Haven't the years been good to Hattie?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: It hasn't been the years; it's been the men in her life.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Boy, I thought you were about to cross the river.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I tell you, I feel like a ghost.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Stranger my foot, it was my grandmother who helped you into this world.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well, I don't want to put you out.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Good evening. It must be all the different time zones I crossed that makes me feel this weary.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You should go back and rest.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No, if I rest any longer, I won't sleep tonight. May I use your bathroom to wash up a bit?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: One can tell you are from back home. These people nowadays don't know what manners are.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Where we come from, you had to know how to act right. You had to know how to say yes sir and no sir. You had to know your place.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Those days you could always find something redeeming about even the worst person.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You remember that boy who lost his mind, Joe? You could hear him pitching horseshoes at night in the dark. He wouldn't miss a one. Make him mad and call yourself running in the house to be safe. He would pick up a brick and say "go on in there brick and hit somebody" and it would find its mark.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I was afraid to go to Marcus Bottom because of him.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: All those places that us coloreds lived, that we used to call Bottoms, have all been changed to Drives and Heights. Everything is in what you call it, not in what it is.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I have someone I want you to meet.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'll be right there.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Harry, you know everything.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You got to know everything, do everything, and be everything.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What's the problem here?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: She has a fish bone caught in her throat. Could all of you go in the other room? Gideon, get some bread and toast it quickly and find me the cod liver oil.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: How is everybody?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Tolerable well.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ah, you young folks don't know how it is. How is Gideon today?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: He wasn't able to get out of bed today.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I hope that it's nothing serious.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: He has never gotten rid of the malaria. He is usually up and at it the next day. I'm going to make him fresh chicken broth.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Let me earn my keep. I'll go out and get a hen and have it picked and ready for the pot. Try to make him some cow tea next time.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Can you watch Gideon for a while? One of the girls is going into labor. Junior is going to drive me over.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You just run along. I'll fix him his soup. He will be all right.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That smells like fresh coffee.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Let me get you a cup?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Only if you can spare it.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: How is he doing?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: As long as he keeps his throat clear, he is able to get some rest.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I made a fresh pot of coffee. Okra and I thought you need a rest. I'll stand guard. Okra wants to talk to you anyway.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Good afternoon, ladies.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Good afternoon to you.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: As God is my witness, I have never done anything to that woman.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: You must have done something to her.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Since she has repented, all she does is throw stones.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Hattie is a different person now.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I don't make no bones about where I'm going to spend eternity. I have always been wild and you know that. If you are made to feel half a man, what do you think the other half is?

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: I'm glad you brought that up as to who you are. I have to know who is in my house.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You invited me.

turns.speaker: SUZIE
turns.text: Only if you are a good man, a friend. Are you a friend?

turns.speaker: MARSH
turns.text: There is something that I always wanted to know. Tell me, how did those boys die?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Now who are we talking about?

turns.speaker: MARSH
turns.text: Miss Clara's boy, Emory, to start with. The Johnson's Hocker was another one...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Wasn't Hocker lynched?

turns.speaker: MARSH
turns.text: You know as well as I do that it was made to look like he was lynched. Now who would hang someone from a persimmon tree?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What difference does it make if it's persimmon, oak tree or huckleberry bush?

turns.speaker: MARSH
turns.text: Hocker's death almost caused a race riot. A lot of innocent people could have been hurt behind that.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Strange as it may seem, it might have cleared the waters. Sometimes the right action comes from the wrong reason.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I think if anybody had a hand in killing Hocker, you ought to ask or you should have asked Emory and Chick.

turns.speaker: MARSH
turns.text: Chick was outright killed by a mob. He killed a white man that owed him some money and when they caught up with him, they tied him behind a car and dragged him from out of the hills back to town.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Those boys never did have good luck.

turns.speaker: MARSH
turns.text: You damn right they didn't, especially Emory, my cousin.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Emory had made a lot of enemies. He had a big mouth.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: A woman in family way just reminds of spring and my younger days.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: That's nice.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well, you and your husband are special. Ya, Gideon tells me you do volunteer work to help feed the poor.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: How many people do you all feed?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Last Saturday we handed out over two hundred meals.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Good God Almighty, bless your bones.  But the problem grows.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Week by week the crowds at the door keeps getting larger. We can't feed all the hungry.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Of course not. Have you ever heard of a man jumping in the river to save five hundred drowning people? No you ain't.  You have to take just one and fatten him up. When you spread help too thin, you , you just nickel and dime the situation. If you try to save all, all die but if you save one life, life goes on. You just have to remember, medicine that works leaves a bitter taste.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I don't know if we could take one in with Rhonda and me at home alone at times.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, I wasn't pointing my finger at you. Hey, you have to think of yourself. A lot of them have all kinds of diseases and will cut your throat while you sleep. There are too many bad people out there.

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: I couldn't believe it when Suzie called and said you were staying here. How have you been?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Girl, do you still sing and dance?

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: No, I'm a different person now, Harry.

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: Harry, that's not nice. I'm in church now.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Why run out and close the barn door when the horse is gone? I remember when you weren't saved. That was way back yonder when the Natchez Trace was just a dirt road.

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: Some people grow up and change their ways.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I know your mother ain't still operating that house of hers.

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: My mother passed on years ago.

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: None of your business.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That is a boy from home, Lulla's brother.

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: You know the saying, "your heart is in your left hand."

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Now I was trying to be nice, to make conversation, since we go back some.

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: I was quoting from the Bible. If the shoe fits, wear it.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: "Out of weariness, I spoke to my own heart; to leave it all and to die. And I gave my heart to know madness and folly."

turns.speaker: HATTIE
turns.text: An empty wagon makes a lot of noise and you, tappy head, you ain't worth the salt you put in greens.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Speaking of tappy heads, we ought to have an old fashion fish fry.
